displayed_text: Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s nothing in the blood work all your scans are clean, then you can say wow I see nothing Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s what I’m like, that’s what I was trying to tell you. That’s the way he didn’t know what I take. He said you still taking the prednisone Doctor: So you need a new script? Patient: Yeah I need a new script, all of that. Doctor: Because even with this new chemo I need to continue the prednisone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m telling you. Patient: Okay. Okay Doctor V____. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I’m I’m doing anything you want me to. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I’m good. Doctor: Okay so we’ll be back with all that paperwork and stuff. Okay?

Patient: Okay. I wanna discuss with Dr. L___ who is my oncolgoist said I should really Doctor: I communicate with her, etcetera notes, translated to him real time so to speak. Patient: Okay. I understand that you’re Doctor: see in the notes Patient: Um I did a couple of months ago. Yeah because I did something PSA… Doctor: Okay. And did you plans in the future? Patient: It’s open-ended . I wanted Doctor: There might come a time that we might do something perfectly capable… and at that point Patient: Okay. Perfect. Fine. Doctor: Alrighty. Take this with you. It’s the consent form. The next step on my part would be to contact the study team. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Either he or his scheduling staff. And we’ll be in touch with you by telephone.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know I would tell you ditch this and just go get some other treatment. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So for now we gave you the pills for today. Patient: Right. Doctor: So for now you’re okay with keeping on taking it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay and uh we’ll touch base, we’ll let you know of course what the bone scan shows once I look at it. Okay. Family Member 2: Very good. Doctor: Alright. Patient: What do you think. Yeah, Yepthat’s fine.

Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them? Doctor: No. You should not. You’re done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re going to try a new drug, huh, that’s quite expensive, and we have to just be able to figure out if we can get it for you. Patient: Okay. Family Member: I appreciate it. Right. Patient: And how would I find out? Family Member 1: You do nothing. Family Member: You do nothing. They’ll call you. Patient: Oh, you’ll call me? Doctor: I’m not going to call you. The pharmacy will call you. Patient: The pharmacy, right. Family Member: Pharmacy. Right.

Patient: The - The Casodex I don’t – don’t take the Casodex? Doctor: Do you have enough for the next month or so? Patient: Right now I have about, I probably got about a week left of that before they re… Doctor: Okay perfect. Don’t refill it. Patient: Okay, but just take… Doctor: Until I figure this out. Patient: But just take the rest of those? Doctor: And then I’ll have you come back next week. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. (pause doctor whispering) Patient: So finish these off and don’t refill. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’. Patient: But will I – wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, but Dr. P_ just talked about one bag! And you come out with two bags, man! Doctor: Well, you might need two bags. Patient: Woooooooo. Doctor: Where’s the bowel gonna get re-routed? It’s gotta poop somewhere, and you’re got a connection. Patient: Wooooooo. Doctor: It’s two bad organs.

Patient: Okay will it get curlier? Doctor: It got curlier because the old chemotherapy’s outta your system. Patient: Yeah. (Pause5sec) Family Member: Well, so, if I was your dad, what would you do? Let him have to decide? Doctor: Yeah. I, um, I don’t know – I’ve never made a decision for ya. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue is sort of your sense of what you do to your children, brother, what you want to do. You’re physically well enough. You, you know, if you can think about those things, I think a clinical trial makes a lot of sense. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Or my sense is the other thing is, you know, if time was short, I probably would sort of step back and sort of just focus on, you know, good days. Um. So I would sit there on the fence. I’m not ready to give up on myself. I wanna try something versus -- hhh this has all been too much. (Pause4sec) Patient: If it, it, it extends my, my time that I have to wait for a real cure then maybe it’s worth it. Doctor: Well, that reality is pretty slim. You know, we’ve been working on this awhile, and I’m not sure that a cure is gonna just pop up in the next six months, nine months. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And again, we often, er, don’t have drugs that resurrect people. Uh. You can hope. I hope and pray as well. Uh. The reality is, you know, you can keep pluggin’ along. Uh, so I think you’re eligible because you’re physically well enough to get through this.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that’s what we’re following. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right now, there is no evidence that it has gone any place else in your body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But we’ll continue to follow that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Patient: That’s good. That’s good. I’m going to keep the faith that everything is, is good. Doctor: Okay. Now very good. (pause7sec) Patient: I try not to worry. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Don’t worry.

Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay. Doctor: Good. Family Member: I have one more question. Doctor: Yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Because he, when we last saw Dr. V____ in Vegas in July he was telling us there’s some research but it will be seven or eight months out. So that was July so it wouldn’t be until like next month about combining radium with the docetaxel. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so that’s already actually in trial. It is… Family Member: He thought it was better for the body. Doctor: Yeah, it’s not as a home run, you know, there’s nothing that tells me we should do it off road to do that at this moment. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: That’s probably the best way to say it. Nothing that says oh, man, this abstract tells me this is like a home run. No, I think it just adds more side effects. Patient: Yeah, okay, good, okay Doctor: Yeah, so, I know prostate cancer is the one cancer we can’t seem to plot. We love combining stuff. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly.

Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different. Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left. Patient: Yeah something to do with the hip replacement thought too. Doctor: Well the hip replacement always glows so then we always look for the other side to make sure that you don’t have a matching set. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So the issue is if you start to feel it because you’re working more, or you’re lounging more, or doing whatever more up north and you’re aware, but it’s more of an awareness thing not we’re about to do this. Patient: Um hum, um hum. Doctor: People know and this is kind of like you know your right hip wasn’t functioning well before.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So we might as well get an impression of what the bones, what’s going on in the lower back, and all of that, as well as mainly the lymph nodes is what I want to keep an eye on. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I think maybe the Xofigo is still doing its stuff. Patient: Um hum. Yeah. Your husband did a good job. Doctor: As long as everything is in remission. Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: On and off, I guess I’ll compliment him, then. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Right. Right. Yeah. Not too much. Doctor: Not too much. Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Everything went okay and smoothly? Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. I’m fine. Yeah. Patient: So we get the shot right here?
